instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: This board is a potential refurb for a business client. The only history I have on it is that the screen is cracked and that there is "No Display". Upon further investigating the unit gets a green light and fan spin but does not POST. The computer spins up runs for about 30 seconds and then spins down and repeats over and over again. The computer does have proper 8.58 V PPBUS and has 1.75 VCORE. The VCORE rail cycles with the fan spinning. When the computer is spun up and VCORE is high, there is no light on a USB mouse or keyboard. No signs of liquid damage or previous repair. The CPU gets warm but not alarmingly hot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: If this happened after a drop and a cracked LCD there is probably damage under the CPU and/or RAM. Impact damage is usually not fixable.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Is it worth attempting to reflow the CPU / RAM chips with flux?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: If you want to waste time. The traces/pads will probably be ripped up and even if it works I will not consider it a durable or reliable repair.
